In spite
exercises.answer: Regardless
exercises.hint: This adjective acts as a detached modifier, often followed by 'of'.
exercises.example_sentence: Regardless of the weather, the race will go ahead as planned.

exercises.question: Arrange the words to form a 'For + Subject + To-infinitive' clause acting as the sentence subject.
exercises.answer: For a firm to fail to adapt is to invite obsolescence
exercises.hint: The entire 'For... to adapt' phrase functions as the noun subject of the verb 'is'.
exercises.example_sentence: For him to act in such a way was completely out of character.

exercises.question: Match the 'Sophisticated Correlatives' to their respective clauses.
exercises.hint: Pay close attention to the specific conjunctions (that/than/when) paired with the opening phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: Such was his anger that he could barely speak.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of a 'Negative Participle' fronted for emphasis.
options: Not wishing to cause offense, he chose his words carefully.
Wishing not to cause offense, he chose his words carefully.
No wishing to cause offense, he chose his words carefully.
Not to wishing to cause offense, he chose his words carefully.
exercises.answer: Not wishing to cause offense, he chose his words carefully.
exercises.hint: The negative 'not' always precedes the present participle in these introductory clauses.
exercises.example_sentence: Not knowing the way, I had to ask for directions.

exercises.question: The project was delayed, ___ to a lack of technical resources.
options: owing
due
because
thanks
exercises.answer: owing
exercises.hint: While 'due to' is common, 'owing to' is often preferred at the start of a clause or after a comma in formal registers.
exercises.example_sentence: Owing to the rail strike, the meeting has been canceled.

exercises.question: Order the words to form an 'Absolute Construction' describing a completed state.
exercises.answer: The sun having set the travelers decided to make camp
exercises.hint: The 'subject + having + past participle' phrase functions independently of the main clause.
exercises.example_sentence: The meeting having concluded, we all went to lunch.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'It' as an 'Empty Object' followed by a 'Whether' clause?
options: I leave it to you whether we should proceed or not.
I leave to you whether we should proceed or not.
I leave it whether we should proceed or not to you.
I leave that whether we should proceed or not to you.
exercises.answer: I leave it to you whether we should proceed or not.
exercises.hint: The 'it' serves as a placeholder for the object clause that follows the prepositional phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: I find it strange whether he arrives on time or not.

exercises.question: Match the 'Nominal Relative Pronouns' to their meanings.
exercises.hint: These pronouns often introduce clauses that act as subjects or objects.
exercises.example_sentence: Whoever designed this building was a genius.

exercises.question: Identify the correct 'Passive Subjunctive' in a formal 'That-clause'.
options: It is essential that the evidence be preserved for future study.
It is essential that the evidence is preserved for future study.
It is essential that the evidence should be preserved for future study.
It is essential that the evidence were preserved for future study.
exercises.answer: It is essential that the evidence be preserved for future study.
exercises.hint: The mandative subjunctive (be + past participle) is the most formal option after adjectives of importance.
exercises.example_sentence: The law requires that the public be notified of any changes.

exercises.question: The CEO's decision was ___ in a desire to improve long-term sustainability.
options: rooted
fixed
placed
set
exercises.answer: rooted
exercises.hint: A metaphorical verb often used in formal English to describe the origin or cause of an idea/policy.
exercises.example_sentence: The conflict is deeply rooted in historical grievances.

exercises.question: Order the words to form a 'Comparative Inversion' with 'Had'.
exercises.answer: The event was more spectacular than had been originally anticipated
exercises.hint: The auxiliary verb 'had' precedes the participle 'been' in this formal 'than' clause.
exercises.example_sentence: The costs were higher than had been projected.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'Should' for an 'Accidental' or 'Tentative' future?
options: If you should happen to see him, please give him my regards.
If you would happen to see him, please give him my regards.
If you should to happen to see him, please give him my regards.
Should if you happen to see him, please give him my regards.
exercises.answer: If you should happen to see him, please give him my regards.
exercises.hint: 'Should' (often with 'happen to') makes the condition feel less likely or more accidental.
exercises.example_sentence: If anyone should call, tell them I'll be back in an hour.

exercises.question: Match the 'Complex Conjunctions' to their grammatical roles.
exercises.hint: Notice which of these require a full sentence (clause) and which require just a noun phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: Given that he is only 18, his performance was remarkable.

exercises.question: Identify the correct formal use of 'But' as a preposition meaning 'Except'.
options: No one but the authorized personnel may enter this area.
No one but the authorized personnel can enter this area.
No one but the authorized personnel will enter this area.
No one but the authorized personnel should enter this area.
exercises.answer: No one but the authorized personnel may enter this area.
exercises.hint: 'But' is a formal alternative to 'except' when used after 'no one', 'everyone', etc.
exercises.example_sentence: I have nothing but praise for the team.

exercises.question: The negotiations have been ___ by a series of unfortunate misunderstandings.
options: marred
broken
hurt
hit
exercises.answer: marred
exercises.hint: A sophisticated verb meaning to impair the appearance or quality of something.
exercises.example_sentence: The beauty of the landscape was marred by industrial development.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a 'Relative Clause' using 'the extent to which'.
exercises.answer: The report highlights the extent to which the crisis has affected the region
exercises.hint: This phrase is used to discuss the degree or amount of an effect.
exercises.example_sentence: They are still assessing the extent to which the damage can be repaired.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'It' to emphasize a 'Subject'?
options: It was the Director who authorized the expenditure.
It was the Director which authorized the expenditure.
It was the Director what authorized the expenditure.
It was the Director whom authorized the expenditure.
exercises.answer: It was the Director who authorized the expenditure.
exercises.hint: In a cleft sentence focusing on a person, use 'who' or 'that'.
exercises.example_sentence: It was the rain that caused the delay.

exercises.question: Match the 'Future in the Past' constructions.
exercises.hint: These all describe how we looked at the future from a point in the past.
exercises.example_sentence: The flight was due to depart at 6 PM, but it was grounded.

exercises.question: Identify the correct 'Negative Inversion' with 'Only after'.
options: Only after the investigation is complete will the results be released.
Only after the investigation is complete the results will be released.
Only after is the investigation complete will the results be released.
Only after the investigation is complete will be released the results.
exercises.answer: Only after the investigation is complete will the results be released.
exercises.hint: The inversion occurs in the main clause, not the 'Only after' clause.
exercises.example_sentence: Only after I had reached the station did I realize I'd forgotten my ticket.
